div.p:
Hic quaeri solet Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 7, c. 1, (I, 91, ll. 15-16). . This is distinction 7 of the first book which continues with respect to the preceding because after the Master determined about divine generation with respect to mode and form, he begins here to determine about those thing that have to do with the power of acting. And he divides this into two because in the first place he inquires whether the power of generating belongs to Father eternally, secondly whether this power is found in the Son. The second begins at
item quaeritur a quibusdam Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 7, c. 2, (I, 93, ll. 20). .

The first in three parts because he first moves the question, second he introduces his determination about it, in the third place from the words of Augustine he offer an explanation of some objection. The second begins at
cui versutiae Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 7, c. 1, (I, 91, ll. 19). . The third begins at
sed vehementer Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 7, c. 1, (I, 92, ll. 6-7). .

The second principal part is divided
in three. The first moves the question and puts its response, secondly he shows the explanation of his response. The second begins at Secunda ibi,
ita etiam, cum dicitur Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 7, c. 2, (I, 94, ll. 17). . And this is the opinion and division in general of the present distinction.
Whether active generation in the Father is of immense perfection absoltely.

That not, no suppositable ratio speaks a perfection, therefore there is not an active generation. The consequence holds because active generatio is a suppositable ratio of the Father. The antecedent is clear because then in the divine there would be another goodness besides the essential goodness. Likewise because to not produce, would be to argue an imperfection, and thus neither the divine essence nor the Holy Spirit would be essentially perfect.

In the second place, it would follows that every divine person would not be as perfect as the essence. The consequence is clear because any person lacks some supposibile ratio becase the Father does not have the suppositable ratio of the Son, nor of the Holy Spirit, nor of the converse.

In the third place, it would follow that the theologian evidently would be able to prove that there is generation in the divine. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because it is evidently able to be deduced that whatever God is, he is everything that it is better to be than not to be absolutely, since he
that which nothing greater is able to be thought Anselmus, Prosologion 3, (I, 103, ll. 1-2). , as says
Anselm in Prosologion .
In opposition, the generation in the divine is the Father, but the Father is of immense perfection or is immense perfection, therefore.

div.head: First conclusion
div.p:
First conclusion: though from the Son and the Holy Spirit no divine word is able to be generated, nevertheless something is producible through the speaking of the Son or the Holy Spirit. The first is clear because otherwise there would be many possible words in the divine, indeed de facto this should be put against faith. The second part is proved because through the speaking of the whole Trinity all created things are produced and producibile things are able to be produced. This is clear through that Psalm
he spoke and things were made Psalmus 32:9 et Psalmus 148:5 . Again John 1
through him all things were made Ioannes 1:3 .

First corollary: that not every speaking with the word speaks the word, though perhaps the converse is true. This is clear because speaking the divine word is precisely and properly to the Father, but speaking with the word suits three, as is clear through the conclusion. From which it seems to follow that, though every internal speaking is understanding, nevertheless not every understanding is speaking.

The second corollary: the eternal productive power of the Word is not a pure relation or merely something related. This is clear because a relation is not a ratio of the Father's being absolutely, therefore it is not a ratio of acting. From which it seems to follow that just as the essence is the ratio of the Father's being, so also it seems to be the ratio of producing the Word. From which it follows further that power of generating the divine word speaks something absolute with respect to what is principally signified, though he knows with respect to what is begotten.

The third corollary: though the word has being and act from the Father, nevertheless the Father and Son produce equally freely. This is clear because the Son is not determined by the Father with some natural necessity, therefore they produce the Holy Spirit equally freely, just as the Father himself generates the word. The antecedent is clear from what has been said above. Further it follows that it is as repugnant to the Word to intrinsecally depend as it is necessarily repugnant to it that the Father demanded or needed.
This is clear because all things convey an imperfection. This corollary is against
Scotus, in book one, distinction 6 Scotus, I, d. 6, xxx .

Third conclusion: that though it is not a kind of perfection in generation that something is produced through it from non being to being, nevertheless that something is able to generate, because that being is not evidently probable, is absolutely a kind of immense perfection. The first part is clear because, if this were so, it would follow that divine generation would lack some perfection absolutely. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because the Son neither through generation nor through some other is produced from non being to being. The second part is proved because, if this were so, it would follow that the that God is three would be efficaciously demonstrable and would be evidently proved. The consequent was disproved earlier. The consequence is clear because the duality of the persons and the trinity of them would be proved in the same way. The third part is proved because it would be able to produce a finite word and would be a perfection of a created memory. Therefore the power to produce the uncreated will be an immense perfection of uncreated memory. This is confirmed because the understanding
of the father is an immense perfection, therefore. The consequence is clear because to speak of the Father is to speak formally his understanding, and consequently it is a vital act and a kind of immense perfection.

First corollary: it is not of lesser perfection to speak the notional aspect of the Father as it is to understand his intrinsic and essential aspect. This is proved because each is of immense perfection, as is clear through the conclusion.

The second corollary: as he is able formally to be blessed in his notional utterance so he is able to be beatified in his essential understanding. This is clear because the Father is beatified formally in his every immense perfection. And these are two corollaries against the position of
Scotus, in distinction 6 of the first book .

Third corollary: no reason separated from faith and clear vision certifies why the Father in the divine does not produce or generate many words or many sons. I mean this according to the common law. This is clear because it is believed by faith alone that only one person in the divine is able to be generated. This is confirmed because every potency and perfect which the Father has, the Son and Holy Spirit have, there by this reason it is not able to be convincingly concluded that he would not be able to produce many sons. This is clear from what has been said. From this the responsive corollary is clear that, though the generation of the eternal word is absolutely immense perfection, nevertheless the negation of it not in one either is the privation of perfection or not, nevertheless the negation of it in one is the privation of perfection. This is clear through Lord Giles, in distinction four of book 1, part 1, question 2, in the solution of the first principal argument where he says
something is a kind of perfection in one supposite that is not a perfection in the other, therefore, though is a kind of perfection in the Son that it is generated, nevertheless it is not necessary that is a kind of perfection in the Father and Holy Spirit Aegidius Romanus, I, d. 4, p. 1, q. 2 . This corollary is also apparent through what has been said.

Against the first part of the first conclusion: to that which the principle of generation in the divine in suitable, to the same thing is it suitable to generate the divine word. But the principle of generation suits the Son and the Holy Spirit, therefore. The major is clear because for as much as habit or latitude is proper to the act of generation, it is required to the same degree for the productive principle of the word. The minor is clear because the essence seems to be the principle of generation.

In the second place, the Son and the Holy Spirit have the perfection absolutley which the Father has, therefore from the Son and the Holy Spirit the divine word is able to be generated. The consequence holds because through what has been said to be able to generate is absolutely an immense perfection. The antecedent is a catholic truth.

Against the second and third corollary: if they were true, it would follow that God would act externally merely naturally and necessarily. The consequent is false because he acts merely freely and contingently. The consequence is clear because in the same mode and by the same action God produces his word and his creatures as is clear through the corollaries.

Against the second conclusion: in every producing thing it is required that it has the nature of a produced terminus or of a producing terminus, there the Father in some mode precedes the Son. The consequence holds and the antecedent known because the opposite seems against nature and reason.

In the second place,
the Son is not able to make anything except that which he sees the Father doing
, therefore the Son depends on the Father in his own acts. The antecedent is clear because in the Gospel of John. And the consequence seems known because, if Socrates is not able to act unless he first sees another acting, then it seems that in this acting depends on the other.

In the third place, every thing begun presupposes its own beginning, therefor the Father precedes the Son. The consequence holds because the Father is the beginning of the Son. The antecedent is proved because that the cause exists is prior to its being a cause because it follows, a is a cause, therefore it is, but the converse is not true. But the beginning is not only presupposed by what was begun for the being of its cause or its beginning, but also in its absolute being, therefore.

Against the third corollary: The Father is free from himself and the Son is not but from the Father, therefore the Son is less free than the Father. Consequence is valid and the antecedent is clear because whatever the Son is and has, he has from the Father.

In the second place, from words of Christ in Luke 2
it is necessary for me to be about the things of my Father Lucas 2:49 , therefore he acts necessarily and not freely. The consequence is clear because through the word being it seems that something is conveyed in necessary terms.

Against the last corollary: the Son proceeds both perfectly from the Father in the distinct person and perfectly if it were to proceed
distinct, personally, and essentially, but the Son would depend on the Father and would presuppose him, therefore also now.

Against the second part of the third conclusion: everything that is more communicable the more perfect it is, but therefore God is able to communicate himself by producing. This is probable because most perfect thing is the most communicable thing. This mode is probable because God is the most perfect being.

In the second place, it is repugnant that the intellectual nature is independent that it does not produce some word expressive of it. But the divine essence is of this type, therefore. The minor is known and the major is proved because it is not repugnant to the finite memory to speak itself through a comprehensive word expressive of itself, therefore it is not repugnant to an immense and infinite memory, therefore. The consequence holds because God is comprehensive of himself through his understanding and as a consequence is productive and formative of an immeasurable Word and not through creation, therefore through generation, and the intent is reached. The argument is founded on what is said by Augustine, in the book on the cognition of the blessed life, where he says
since the mind knows itself as if it generates a mind similar to itself Augustinus, De cognitione verae vitae, XI . This is the foundation and means of Hugolinus.

In the third place, whatever is the productive principle from a formal ratio of something according to its own formal ratio in whatever it is will be the productive principle of something from itself. But the intellect having an object present to itself is from the formal ratio the principle of the begotten knowledge, therefore when such a thing is in God, it follows that there is a begotten knowledge there. This is the argument of
Scotus, in distinction 2 of the first book Scotus, I, d. 2 .

Against the second corollary: if it were true, it would follow that the suppositable ratio would be equally the beatificative ratio of the created intellect just as the divine essence. The consequent is false, therefore.
Iohannes de Marchia Ioannes de Marchia, XXX ,

Against the third corollary: relations of the same species are not able to be multiplied unless according to a natural distinction. But such a distinction should not be put in the divine essence, therefore there are many filiations, and as a consequence there are not able to be many sons.
Saint Thomas, in the first part, question 41, article 6 Aquinas, Summa Theologiae I, q. 41, a. 6, resp. (4, 432).

In the second place, precise reason why the Father is not able to generate another Son is because filiation of this type is the total subsisting quantity, hence it is not able to be multiplied.
Aureoli, book 1, distinction 7, question 2, article 3 Aureolus, I, d. 7, q. 2, a. 3 (xxx) .

In the third place, because it is repugnant that there are many relations of the same ratio in the same foundation except on account a diversity of absolutes. But in God there are not able to be many absolute relations, therefore there are not many such relations, and as a consequence there are not many sons.
Ockam, distinction 7 of book 1, question 3, article 2 Ockham, Ordinatio I, d. 7, q. 3 (3, 153, l. 24 - 154, l. 4). .

In the fourth place, the adequate act to a productive principle which is always standing is not compatible with another act of the same ratio from the same principle. But so it is about the act of paternal generation in the divine, therefore there are not able to be many sons.
Henry, quolibet 6, quaestione prima Henricus, Quodlibet VI, q. 1 .

In the fifth place, if there are able to be many productions in the divine of the same reason, then there would be infinite amount. But whatever is able to be in God is there de facto, therefore he would form there infinite generations.
Scotus, in his Quolibet, question 2 Scotus, Quodlibet, q. 2 .

In the sixth place, to produce many knowledges in the divine is absolutely impossible from the fact that this knowledge would not be in the divine nature unless it were God unless absolutely the whole infinite latitude of possible knowledge produced through the mode of knowledge or of the word were the production, therefore. This argument explains why many sons are not generated, and as a consequence is held not only by faith.
Hugolinus, distinction 7 of book 1, question 2, conclusion 2 Hugolinus, I, d. 7, q. 2 , see there.

In the seventh place, the Father is not able to have known himself by a knowledge other than in the mode that he knows himself, therefore he is not able to produce another world. The consequence is known because every word is knowledge. The antecedent is clear because the Father in this case knew himself infinitely as he is his essence to the same degree as he is wisdom, as is clear through
Augustine, De Trinitate, in book XV, chapter 14 Augustinus, De Trinitate, XV, c. 14 . The antecedent is confirmed because either this word would be
more perfect or less or equally perfect. None of these things should be said, therefore.

In the eight place, if he were able to produce another word, then the Father would not have spoken perfectly. The consequent is false. These three arguments are the arguments of
Bonsemblantes which he puts in his first question Bonsemblantes, XXX , in which he asks whether the power of generating is in the Son.

In the ninth place against this corollary, it seems to be the procedure of
Lord Giles, in distinction 7 of book 1, in the last question
Aegidius Romanos, Sent, I, d. 7, P. 2, Q. 4 , where he gives the difference between our word and the divine word. In the first place because the divine word is always born from knowledge, but our word is sometimes born from ignorance. In the second place because the knowledge of God is immutably stable, but our word may be lost. In the third place because the divine word is never unformed, but our word is not always formed. In the fourth place because
the divine word is born from the whole knowledge of the Father , but our word is not able to be formed from all species contained in memory, from which it seems to be concluded the unity of the divine word and the plurality of our word.

div.head: Responses
div.p: To the first, it is said that the statement that the essence is the principle of generation of the divine word is able to be take in two ways. In the first mode as the essence in and of itself absolutely considered, and in this way it is not the principle, nor what generates, nor what is generated. In the other mode it is taken as it subsists in paternity or as it is in the paternal supposite, and in this way it is able to be called the principle of generation, and then the minor is false.
To the second, the consequence is denied because, though that power is a kind of perfection in the Father, nevertheless it is not in the Son or in the Holy Spirit.

In the second place, it is able to be said that, though the Son has every perfection and potency, nevertheless he is not able to execute the act of generation because he does not have the property suited to generation, namely paternity, but the opposite, namely filiation.

In the third place, it would be able to be said that the same perfection and the same power is that by which the Father generates and the son is begotten because they do not differ in any absolute thing.

In the fourth place, when it is said that the Son does not have the power of generating which the Father has this is able to be understood in two ways. In one mode the Son does not have the power of generating, that is by which he is able to generate, and in this sense it is conceded. In another mode he does not have this power by which he is able to be begotten or to be generated or to have been generated by which power the Father is empowered such that he generates, and this sense it is denied.

To the second, the consequence is denied. And to the proof it is said that, if the mode and actions are taken nominally and really, then the antecedent is conceded and the consequence is denied because the mode in which God produces is singular. But if they are taken modally and adverbially, then the antecedent is denied.

To the first against the second conclusion, the antecedent is universally denied and though it has truth in created things, nevertheless it does not in divine things because the measure of divine production within itself is eternity. Therefore there is not a going forward or a precession both by reason of the identify of the essence and by reason of the correlative offering .
To the second, the consequence is denied by reason o the identity of nature.
To the third, by speaking in conformity with what was said above, it would be possible to say that in the divine properly nothing is begun because this conveys and imperfection
In the second place, the antecdent is able to be denied when speaking about supposition or the going forward, just as the conclusion and its corollary ought to be understood.
To the fourth, the consequence is denied by reason of the identity of nature.
To the argument from the passage of Luke, it is said that the word it is necessary does not denote the oportunity of necessity, but rather of congruity.

In the second place, it is said that, if it indicates necessity, it is nevertheless not necessity of the consequent but of the consequence, and this kind of necessity is not repugnant to liberty, but stands with it at the same time.
In the third place, it would be able to be said that it is spoken there according to humanity, but here I speak about the Trinity alone, therefore it does not follow.
To another, the consequence is simply denied.

To the first against the third conclusion, it is said that it does not follow evidently that since God is infinite goodness and liberty, therefore he communicates himself by produces the Son equal to himself because the antecedent
should also be conceded about the divine essence and the Holy Spirit, and nevertheless they do not communicate themselves in that mode.

To the second, the philosopher or adversary of faith would say that, though the uncreated memory understands itself, nevertheless it is not through the word distinct from it really or personally. And they would further say that it would be better and more perfect that the created memory would be it very own intellection or knowledge than understand through a word or knowledge that is distinct from it. Again through the same, it would be able to be concluded that the divine essence would generate the word, which is false.

To the authority of Augustine, it is said that he speaks only about the created mind which is clear through the fact that he says generate as similar to itself because it stands that the divine word absolutely is not as if equal and similar to the Father. And through this Augustine wishes to lead us to the following, that it is in the uncreated mind, but through this he does not convince evidently.
To another, the philosopher and the adversary would deny the major.
To another, it follows that the suppositable ratio, etc. The consequent is conceded.

To the first against the third corollary, it is said that the argument is founded on something false. In the first place that God is not able to multply individuals under one species, error. Again, that forms do not receive division without matter, error. These are two condemned articles upon which the argument seems to founded.

To the second, the antecedent is denied because, if the argument were valid, then it would be possible to be concluded that there are not three persons because every divine person naturally and essentially includes a divine subsisting quantity, as faith holds, therefore in the same mode it follows that it is only one person. The argument is clear from similar matters.

To the third, in the first place the major would be able to be denied by the adversary because
according to Alphonsus Alphonsus Vargas, XXX
it is not more repugnant to be several relations in the same foundations than to be several active things of the same ratio. But the latter
Ockham himself concedes in the same place Ockham, Ordinatio I, d. 7, q. 3 (3, 153, l. 24 - 154, l. 4) , therefore.

To the fourth, it is said that, if the argument were to conclude through similarity, it would be proved that the Father alone would be in the divine, which is false. Therefore the adversary of faith would deny the major.

To the fifth, the consequence is denied concerning the form because it does not follow that because in creatures this is able to generate two sons, therefore it is able generate an infinity of sons because, if this were valid, it would also be able to be inferred that since two persons are produced, therefore an infinity, which is heretical

To the sixth, the antecedent is denied. To the proof it is said that it is not valid because the total latitude of perfection which is in all three persons is in the Father by himself, and likewise the total possible knowledge, and the total love, and the total perfection, from which it would be able to be inferred that there are not many supposites, but only the supposite of the Father. Therefore it is clear that it does not follow that the Son is the total latitude of perfection, etc. Therefore it is thus clear by arguing that the Father is the total perfection of the deity, therefore nothing other beside him is the immense perfection of the deity.

To the seventh, the consequence is denied. To the proof, it is said that it does not show evidently because, though every word is knowledge, nevertheless it would be able to be said that from the same word the knowledge which is the Father would be able to be another word. In the second place, it would be able to said that, granted that the argument would prove that the Father would not be able to beget another word, nevertheless it does not show that the Son is not able to generate. In the third place, it is said that, if the antecedent is taken for knowledge in which, then it supposes that it ought to prove because according to Augustine
the Father knew all things in himself and knew all things in the word Augustinus, XXX . From this it is clear that the word is knowledge in which the Father knew. Therefore to say that the Father is not able to know himself by another knowledge when taking knowledge thus clearly begs the questions because it supposes what is meant to be proved. But if it taken as the knowledge by which the Father knows, then the adversary would deny the first consequence.

Through this it is clear with respect to the eighth that it does not follows that the Father speaks himself perfectly, therefore he is not able to speak another word. And I respond always just as the infidel or adversary of faith would respond.

To the reasoning of Lord Giles it is said that he only intends to prove the difference between the word of God and our word. Nevertheless through this he does not prove evidently that the Father would be able to generate another Son and to spirate another Holy Spirit.

To the first in the opposition, the antecedent is denied. In the second mode it would be able to be said that just as that this is a person does not speak a perfection absolutely, nevertheless to be a person speaks a perfection absolutely, thus to be a supposite speaks a perfection absolutely, though that this is a supposite does not.

To the second, it is clear through the same that, though the supposite of the Father is not the supposite of the Son and not the converse, nevertheless because each is a supposite no perfection is lacking in them.

Hic quaeri solet Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 7, c. 1 (I, 91, ll. 15-16). . This distinction contains four conclusions. First: that the Father generates Son is not something to divine power or to the divine will, nevertheless it is some power or will, and nevertheless it does not follow that the person which is able to do or will this is more powerful than the person which is not able to do this or will this.

The second conclusion: that, though the Son is not able to generate, nevertheless this is not from impotency, but from propriety because it is not necessary that he generate otherwise by the reason that the Son would have generated a descendent, the descendent of the future would have generated another descendent, and thus without ceasing. Therefore the son is not able to be the Father, neither of himself nor of another, and this does not come from the impotency, but from the propriety of generation by which the Son is what it is which is not able to be the Father.

Third conclusion: that the Father is by nature or essence the power to beget the Son, and the same power is in the Son by which he was able to be begotten and in the Father by which he was able to generate.

Fourth conclusion: though it is the same power by which the Father is able to beget and the Son is able to be begotten, nevertheless it is a different property or notion by which the Father is the begetter and the by which Son is begotten, such that when referring to the power to generate and the power to be generate as a property, then the Father has some power which the Son does not have and vice versa. And this power is notional and relative because it does not speak the what but the toward, whence it does not follow that the Father has the power generating and the Son not, therefore the Father has some potency or some power that the Son does not have. Rather the Father generates by the same power with whichh the Son is generated because the Father is able to generate and the Son is able to be generated. In the same way likewise it does not follow that the Father has a potency which is the Father and the that the Son does not have this, therefore the Father has some potency which the Son does not have.
